name: Blue-winged Kookaburra
description: It has a beige body with black cross-stripes on the chest and belly, brown scapular feathers, light blue primary and secondary flight feathers, a blue rump, and a white iris. Males have a dark blue tail with a white edge, while females have a rufous tail with dark bars. Like all kookaburras, it has a robust beak.
image_alt: Blue-winged Kookaburra, photo: Prague Zoo Archive
proportions: Body length 15–25 cm; tail 12–14 cm; wing length 21–24 cm; weight 250–370 g
attractions: Kookaburras are larger relatives of kingfishers and fishers but are less tied to water, often hunting in open, arid landscapes. They perch on elevated spots, scanning for insects and small vertebrates, including snakes, which they kill with their strong, up to 8 cm long beak. Kookaburras are social birds, constantly calling to each other with a harsh, laugh-like voice familiar to Australians. Indeed, the kookaburra is so integral to the Australian landscape that it became a mascot for the 2000 Sydney Olympics. Females lay eggs in tree hollows or termite nests. Kookaburras adapt easily to human presence and can be kept in aviaries, living up to 20 years in captivity.
breeding: In 1997 and 1998, the first blue-winged kookaburras arrived from Rotterdam, raising their first chick in 2002. Breeding has continued uninterrupted since then.
